author: Miguel de Cervantes
review: The most popular novel of all time, Don Quixote, is a testament to how great storytelling has no expiration date. The story follows a Hidalgo, Alonso Quixano, who proves that chivalry will, in fact, never die.

author: Charles Dickens
review: Chances are, you read A Tale of Two Cities (or at least pretended to) in a high school class. It's no surprise that this novel has sold so many copies—it's practically mandatory.

author: J.R.R. Tolkien
review: The best-selling fantasy novel series, The Lord of the Rings, has only grown in popularity since it was released, spawning a veritable armada of films, theatre, music, artwork, video games, and even board games.

author: Antoine de Saint-Exupéry
review: The Little Prince, a book about the perils of growing old by French aristocrat Antoine de Saint-Exupéry, has been translated into more than 300 languages and dialects.

author: J.R.R. Tolkien
review: This relatively brief novel set the stage for J.R.R. Tolkien's later work, The Lord of the Rings. In The Hobbit, or There and Back Again, we follow protagonist Bilbo Baggins and accompany him on a treasure hunt gone wrong.

bookName: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone
author: J.K. Rowling
review: In the first installment of the massively popular series, Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone—otherwise known as Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone—a boy finds out, not only that he's a wizard, but that he's already famous in a world he doesn't know.
